text: Oxygala () (i.e. sour milk), known today as xinogala (), was an ancient Greek dairy product consumed in the cuisines of ancient Greece and Rome. Oxygala is believed to have been a form of yogurt Dalby, p. 66 and was usually eaten with honey. ==See also== * Greek Yogurt * List of dairy products ==References== ==Bibliography== * Dalby, A. Siren Feasts: A History of Food and Gastronomy in Greece. London: Routledge, 1996. Category:Ancient Greek cuisine Category:Ancient dishes Category:Condiments Category:Roman cuisine
title: Oxygala
